description: A property must have a unique name in its namespace.
An element name must begin with an upper case letter.
An attribute name must begin with a lower case letter.
A term in a property name that does not exist in the dictionary must be defined as Local Terminology.
An abstract element should probably not have a data type.
An element that is not abstract must have a complex data type.
An attribute must have a simple data type.
A property's data type must exist.
A term in a property definition that does not exist in the dictionary should be defined as "Local Terminology".
A property's substitution group must exist.
A property's substitution group must be valid (element and has a compatible type).
An abstract property must be an element.
A property with a substitution group must be an element.
Type namespace prefixes must be defined.
Simple types must have a name.
Complex types must have a name.
Type names must use valid characters.
validExample: Type name "PersonType" uses valid characters.
invalidExample: Type name "ID#Type" does not use valid characters.

description: Type names must end with the representation term "Type".
validExample: Type name 'PersonType' is valid.
invalidExample: Type name 'Person' is not valid.

description: Simple type names must end with the representation term "SimpleType".
validExample: Type name 'IDSimpleType' is valid if the type is simple.
invalidExample: Type name 'IDType' is not valid if the type is simple.

description: Complex type names must not end with the representation term "SimpleType".
validExample: Type name 'IDSimpleType' is valid if the type is simple.
invalidExample: Type name 'IDSimpleType' is not valid if the type is complex.

description: Simple types that use the representation term "CodeSimpleType" must declare codes.
validExample: Type name 'WeekdayCodeSimpleType' is valid if the type declares codes.
invalidExample: Type name 'WeekdayCodeSimpleType' is not valid if the type does not declare codes.

description: Augmentation type names must end with the representation term "AugmentationType".
validExample: Type name 'PersonAugmentationType' is a valid augmentation type name.
invalidExample: Type name 'PersonType' is not a valid augmentation type name.

description: Association type names must end with the representation term "AssociationType".
validExample: Type name 'PersonLocationAssociationType' is a valid association type name.
invalidExample: Type name 'PersonLocationType' is not a valid association type name.

description: Metadata type names must end with the representation term "MetadataType".
validExample: Type name 'SourceMetadataType' is a valid metadata type name.
invalidExample: Type name 'SourceType' is not a valid metadata type name.

description: Simple list type names must end with the representation term "ListSimpleType".
validExample: Type name 'DecimalListSimpleType' is a valid list type name.
invalidExample: Type name 'DecimalValuesSimpleType' is not a valid list type name.

description: Complex types that use the representation term "CodeType" must have a base type that uses the representation term "CodeSimpleType".
validExample: Type name 'WeekdayCodeSimpleType' is not valid if the type does not declare codes.
invalidExample: Type name 'WeekdayCodeType' is not valid with base type 'string'

description: Complex types that use the representation term "CodeType" should be named similarly to their base type.
validExample: Type name 'HairColorCodeType' is valid with base type 'HairColorCodeSimpleType'.
invalidExample: Type name 'HairColorCodeType' is not recommended with base type 'EyeColorCodeSimpleType'.

description: Type names must not occur more than once in a single namespace.
validExample: Types 'justice:CaseType' and 'logistics:CaseType' are valid because even though they use the same name, they are defined in different namespaces.
invalidExample: Type name 'CaseType' cannot be defined twice in the same namespace.

description: Type names should not use the term "Type" in the name other than as the final representation term.
validExample: Type name 'IDCategoryCodeType' is valid because the term 'Type' only appears at the end of the name.
invalidExample: Type name 'IDTypeCodeType' is not valid because the term 'Type' is used in the middle of the name.

description: Type names must begin with an upper case letter.
validExample: Type name 'PersonType' is valid because it begins with an upper case letter.
invalidExample: Type name 'personType' is not valid because it begins with a lower case letter.

description: Type names must use terms that either have standard dictionary entries or are custom defined as Local Terminology.
validExample: Type name 'ncic:VMOCodeType' is valid if the ncic namespace defines the meaning of 'VMO' in its Local Terminology section.
invalidExample: Type name 'ncic:VMOCodeType' is not valid if the ncic namespace does not defined 'VMO' in its Local Terminology section.
notes: NDR rule does not mention local terminology.

description: Simple types must have a definition.
Complex types must have a definition.
Complex type definitions must begin with the standard opening phrase "A data type".
validExample: Definition 'A data type for a human being' is valid for type 'PersonType'.
invalidExample: Definition 'A human being' is not valid for type 'PersonType'.

description: Simple type definitions must begin with the standard opening phrase "A data type".
validExample: Definition 'A data type for United States state codes' is valid for type usps:StateCodeSimpleType.
invalidExample: Definition 'United States state codes' is not valid for type usps:StateCodeSimpleType.

description: Type definitions should use words and terms that are either defined in the dictionary or as "Local Terminology".
validExample: Definition 'A data type for FIPS state codes" is valid if the term 'FIPS' is defined as Local Terminology in that namespace.
invalidExample: Definition 'A data type for FIPS state codes" is not recommended if the term 'FIPS' is not defined as Local Terminology in that namespace.

description: Types must have a style.
Type styles should be one of the following: object, adapter, association, augmentation, CSC, simple, list, union, or blank (defaults to "object").
Types with names that end with "AugmentationType" must have style "augmentation".
Types with names that end with "AssociationType" must have style "association".
Types with names that end with "MetadataType" must have style "metadata".
Types that represent a value (simple content) must declare a base type.
validExample: Type HairColorCodeSimpleType needs a base type like xs:string or xs:token.
invalidExample: Type HairColorCodeSimpleType is not valid without a base type.

description: Complex types with simple content (CSC) must have a simple or CSC base type.
validExample: Simple content type HairColorCodeType can have a base type like HairColorCodeSimpleType (simple type).
invalidExample: Simple content type HairColorCodeType cannot have a type like nc:PersonType (complex object type).

description: Simple types should use a XML schema simple type as its base type.
validExample: Simple type ext:HairColorCodeSimpleType can have base type xs:token.
invalidExample: Simple type ext:HairColorCodeSimpleType should not have base type ext:ColorCodeSimpleType.

description: Types must have bases that are defined.
validExample: Type PersonType can extend type structures:ObjectType (this type exists).
invalidExample: Type PersonType cannot extend type structures:BogusType (this type does not exist).

description: Augmentation types must extend structures:AugmentationType.
Association types must extend another association type.
Metadata types must extend structures:MetadataType
Simple union types must not have a base type
A facet must have a type namespace prefix.
A facet must have a valid type namespace prefix.
A facet must have a type name.
A facet must have a valid type name.
A facet must belong to a simple type.
An enumeration must belong to type with a name that ends in "CodeSimpleType"
A facet must have a value (e.g., code value, pattern value, etc).
A facet value should probably be unique within its type.
An enumeration must have a definition.
A pattern should probably have a definition.
A facet must have a valid style (e.g., enumeration, pattern, etc.).
